reviews.review_msg: Classes were super boring only because the material is dry. No textbook, just lecture slides and assigned articles so be prepared to read a lot. But overall, Snjezana is super kinda and approachable. She was always willing to help out and talk to you during office hours if you ever needed help with assignments/papers. I'd definitely recommend her!

BEST SFU PROF BY FAR. I really enjoy taking classes with this instructor. It's a shame she doesn't teach other psychology courses. It is always a pleasure to interact with her. I would say build a rapport with her

The course is hard, the readings are Very difficult. But, Snjez is an amazing professor, she is always there to help. I absolutely adore her, she is so lovely, and committed to her students. The best professor I have had so far at SFU.
Snej is an amazing prof. She's so understating, and always willing to help her students. However, the course material is not easy and requires a lot of reading.

Snjez is probably one of the most genuine and caring teacher's I've had. I really appreciated how much she goes out of her way to try and make sure every student is learning. At first I found her teaching kind of vague, but after a while you'll get the hang of it. Overall the course was dry, but I do feel like I learnt a lot.

She is a real gem, I have so much respect for her. Not only is she kid and funny, but unlike other profs I have experienced, she actually cares about her students, and will go above and beyond to help them. Everyone should experience her as a prof, because you will not find a more caring and intelligent professor here at SFY

Uses long quotes to explain concepts, the concept itself is often embedded in the quote, so you need to know what the concept is to understand the whole quote. Willing to make changes to a class structure based on opinions held by a minority of students. For example, 20/100+ students wanted her to stop explaining long quotes, so she did
Snej was an amazing, helpful prof. Anyone who says otherwise doesn't belong in a university setting. If you go seek help, it is there for you and she is very understudying.

Classes are very confusing. Most slides have very extensive quotes and are very hard to follow. Even though she uses a microphone, her voice is very soft, and it is very hard to keep up. The tutorials are way better, and the class will definitely depend on your TA.
She was awesome and super helpful!

I was always confused. At times I'm not sure she is sure what information she wants you to take away. That being said she is sessional and this was her first time teaching the course and truly wants to be accommodating and helpful. Lots of time outside the class to try and understand the material -take a tutorial section with her as opposed to TA.

Lots of reading. The first half of the semster is harder than the second half. My TA this semster was useless and often gave information different from what the prof said. Tests are easy as she gives you the short and long answer questions a week before to prepare. Careful with assignments as they're graded hard for being so small.

Super dedicated and interested in the material she teaches. She held extra group office hours to discuss the articles (in addition, to the TA office hours). Reading ahead of class is a must, since she likes to discuss the articles in class and answer any questions based on the notion that the articles have been read
She is probably the nicest prof I have ever had in university.

Usually I can deal with tough profs but this was next level. I found that Dr. Gordon regularly contradicted information from the textbook, was unorganized, and the tests/quizzes included so many trick questions or were poorly worded. I failed almost every single quiz despite it being open book, and I put in an insane amount of hours into this class

I took psyc 308 with Dr. Gordon and was nervous having heard bad things about her classes; however, the class is not nearly as bad as everyone says it is. Yes her teaching can sometimes be confusing, and the online quizzes are difficult, but she does scale grades. Going to lecture is important though since her slides don't make sense on their own.
Iris Gordon once said to the lecture (after dismissing those who wanted to leave early) "I hope those who left early get yeast infections" not sure how this lady is a prof, but here we are.

I think Dr. Gordon gets a bad rep. She was nice and pretty fair as to what she expected. The quizzes, exams, and content in general were difficult sometimes but she marked the papers fairly easily and allocates an extra 5% to the highest scoring exam. She can be slow at replying to emails.

well this might be an unpopular opinion going through the reviews but i genuinely enjoyed this class. i found the textbook surprisingly really funny and engaging and tbh i didn't find dr gordon disorganized at least in 308. the quizzes were tricky for sure but i think fair with the mastery grading system  plus the grading policy is pretty generous

Reviews are right and I deeply regret not listening to these earlier.Not only is her class poorly delivered and disorganized, but she is also not fit to be a prof. She tries to act hip and cool by swearing in every sentence that she speaks. I was severely uncomfortable every lecture (and this has never happened to me before). Worst prof I ever had

never written a review for any of my profs at SFU, but the organization of this class is seriously lacking. quizzes are open book but super hard, and some answers are found on pages that aren't listed on the required reading pages? very confusing. some questions 0.5 marks should be given, but not. i'm sure she's nice but not the best at teaching

The reviews are telling the truth... do not take a class with her. I thought how bad could it be? Turns out... incredibly so. Everything about the class is uncoordinated. She might seem nice first class but don't fall for it!

This has been one of the most challenging experiences with a professor. The lectures were often confusing, and seeking clarification only resulted in feeling belittled rather than gaining understanding. The questions on the exams seemed disconnected from the lecture slides and textbook content

If you value your grades/sanity, never take a class with her. I can't get over how frequently & fluently she made facts up, & then made us feel stupid when we couldn't confirm the idea existed, or found evidence contradicting her. Probably why she warns against outside sources--even the textbook & other profs. Also lied about quiz grades!
I enjoyed her class, it was tough at times but its not impossible to do well. She has a good sense of humour. Recommend!

The fact that the average for the quizzes was 45% that were mind you OPEN BOOK, should tell you a lot about how she manages this course. Her tests are all filled with misleading questions, and some of them blatantly contradict what the textbook or lecture says. If you try and correct her, she'll respond in the most passive-aggressive way possible.

If you typically ignore RateMyProf ratings as I do, I encourage you to take heed to the 105 1-star ratings in Iris's collection. Lecture material and readings are incompatible and insufficient for success. Evidently considers herself a benevolent, capable instructor; I'm not sure whether she suffers from a lack of self-awareness, or of compassion.

Id rather swallow a box of blades than take a class with her. Probably the worst professor at SFU. Run if you ever had to take class with her. Whoever hired her should be responsible because Iris is not a good professor. Ruined my whole experience at SFU

I've had Dr. Gordon as a prof for several classes and I really enjoy her teaching style. Lectures are entertaining and engaging, quizzes are difficult but doable, and office hrs are highly recommended. She's easy to approach and hilarious. Course content is difficult so go to all lectures to understand how info connects. Take thorough notes!

Amount of additional time you have to put into studying and trying to decipher the lecture content/slides is unbelievable. The textbook is absolutely useless for the test content (both quizzes and exams). Also don't bother asking her for help. She won't provide you an answer. Avoid. AVOID!!! For your mental wellbeing... A V O I D.

Tests and quizzes do not relate to textbook or lecture content. You can study for hours and get a bad grad vice versa. Confusing notes, inaccurate information, class average was very low esp for each quiz, one was at 2.75/9. Worst class, IF YOUR REGISTERED FOR THE SPRING OR FUTURE SEMESTERS DROP IT WHILE YOU CAN!!!!

Iris is an ok prof. But her teaching style makes it extremely difficult to even pass. She made all our exams online and its still hard to even get a 50%. Does don't take test questions from textbooks at all.. Sad cause the course content is so interesting but I was not engaged as i was fighting for my life

WTF. This prof seems very interesting in the class, presenting a very nice image in front of students. However, her quizzes and exams are extremely confusing. The answer that follows a correct logic is the wrong answer. The questions in the quiz and exam are very confusing.

If I saw those comment earlier on this website, I would not take this cour
Avoid taking classes with this prof at any cost. She goes off topic the entire class and and words exam questions in a way that are super difficult to understand

I like her a lot as a person, she's very funny; however, the content she focuses on lacks any proportional value on tests. I look back at the power-points and readings and find ... not a single example of something asked on a test. A very confusing and disorganized format.

She seems very passionate about what she teaches and she can be funny. However, her quizzes and exams are difficult, they do not really relate to the lectures or readings. Half the time your saying to yourself ''where was this in the notes/readings?''. Theres multiple answers that seem correct and its confusing when you get ur test back

For her first time teaching the course, I'd say she has done a fantastic job. She tried hard to make the class interesting and engaging, even sometimes can be boring since material is a bit dry to me. Her lectures are short and concise, yet very clear. He exams are straight forward and pretty easy, and her take home final is not bad either.

I thought history of psyc was going to be really boring. Jennifer made it easy to understand and interesting bcuz it wasn't all just names and dates, she had stories to go along with it too. She showed some interesting videos in class. She's a really organized prof and marks tests fairly.

Lectures felt a bit unorganized and strayed far from the textbook, even though the quizzes were based a lot on textbook information. Written assignments had unclear guidelines but he was accessible outside of class for questions. As a person he is very caring and funny, but I would not take another class with him.

I've spent 4 years at SFU so far and never once felt THIS compelled to write a review for any professor-- if you're lucky enough to get Bert as a professor or TA, do it. Bert is the funniest, kindest, and most respectful faculty member I've interacted with throughout my entire undergrad. Treated everyone like equals, no prof/student inequality.

BERT IS INCREDIBLE! I've never had a prof so dedicated, passionate, and supportive. He takes time to explain, encourages questions, and makes every class exciting. He truly wants his students to succeed, and it shows. I still think about what I learned from the course to this day. Take any class with him if you get the chance!

Took 308 with Sager, and overall it was a decent course, not too difficult but challenging all the same. Real trouble started because he would encourage students to reach out if help was needed for the final paper but then email back saying he was "too busy" to go over materials. Don't offer then?? lmao

He is a very good prof! I'd say his TA marked a bit hard, I got 70% on my first part of the assignment he gives but I followed all the guidelines. Other than that, he is super easy to reach, literally treats you as an equal, and will always go out of his way to assist you outside of class if you need it.

Bert was a great prof. His lectures are quite amusing despite the bland topic of this course-- he makes it enjoyable. Lots of readings, but the quizzes are open-book online so it's not that bad. He is very to the point and doesn't deal with BS, so his emails can come off short, but he response within like 5-30mins from sending. I recommend.

Mr. Sager was the best professor I've had in my four years at SFU by FAR. He is kind, funny, friendly, and an open-minded guy. Unlike many other profs, he seems like he sees his students as equals rather than inferiors to him, & he tries to be as unbiased as possible when teaching abt certain subjects. I reallyyy hope I get him again!!!

Bert is a lovely person and professor. He cares about teaching a quality course and is really engaged with the material. I was dreading taking this course as I did not originally want to take it but he made it enjoyable!

quite helpful, passionate, has clear expectations. marking was a bit slow but understandable. make sure to take notes during lec. expect a lot of writing. some people think it's boring as she really goes into a lot of detail and repeats herself a lot but i liked it, was like storytelling. philosophy of science handout important!

Talks pretty fast, assignments are quite difficult, and too much information to know for exams - honestly, quite a difficult course if you've already got a heavy course load and other difficult courses. The content is boring, and she just makes it worse.

Kate definitely packs a lot of info into her lectures, and her exams / assignments require critical thinking not just memorization. A lot of her assignments / exam questions are framed as "synthesis" Qs - how different ideas/people/perspectives relate or contrast with others. So be prepared to make some charts.

Her lectures are brutal,if you ever want to know every tiny minuscule unimportant detail of the history of psychology, then hear it five times over take this class. Listening to them again for the final made me want to rip my hair out. If she could make her point without explaining the meaning of every word she uses, she would be an awesome prof

When I took this course, it was in person and we were graded on 3 papers and 2 small assignments. He's a funny guy but I wouldn't recommend taking classes with him. His lectures are so dry and he's not good at teaching his subject. Just don't take the course unless it's your last option.

The content is extremely dry but Tim is very funny and down to earth, his presence alone makes me want to take any of his classes again. He is very transparent and happy to help you if you need clarification. We had 3 term papers (very open-ended which is nice but hard to know what he was looking for - really just depends on your TA) and no final.

One of the best professors I've had at SFU, if not the best. He is hilarious and makes what would be a boring course really entertaining and honestly quite stress free. Great teacher, even better human. The world would be a better place if everyone was like Tim! Highly highly highly recommend.

I'm not a psych major but I really enjoyed this class. The assignments were straight forward and as long as you tentatively listened to lecture and read the assigned articles, the exams were easy peasy. If you put in the effort, this class is an easy A. Dr. Racine is also pretty sarcastic so it made class more fun. Overall, great experience!
best prof makes everything seem easy, good course structure

I found Tim very good at making this dry course less boring. He acknowledges that it is not very interesting and does his best. For these reasons, he made this class a nice break from my other classes despite the complicated and dry content. The only thing is his lectures go off topic sometimes and rambles. Besides that I recommend this class.

fantastic prof! i loved his lectures -- he's really funny and makes lectures interesting. i'm not the most well-versed in philosophy (which is what this course is based on) but he explained stuff very well. it was a decent course: two participation papers, two take-home exams, and two critical evaluation essays. would totally take his class again!

Tim was hilarious and I loved his pre-lecture rambles and memes he includes. That being said the material is Bone Dry. It was so hard to keep up with listening to lectures and reading because the material is so dense and complex. Tim is very passionate and knowledgeable of the material. Definitely a 'Get Ready To Read' type of course.

Tim's take on online classes was to turn the previously known in class multiple choice exams into take home, written answer exams with a word limit. The grading criteria was unclear, not to mention I was forced to have comparative grades imposed on me. I went to the TAs for feedback and one of them told me that they just had to keep the average low

Tim's a good prof. He's funny and super intelligent, but dang this course SUCKS. It's so dry and honestly I don't understand why its required. He's a good prof but his tutor markers are tough markers. He's a good dude and he's very passionate about what he teaches, so if I HAD to take 308 again, it would definitely be with him.

Tim Racine is the BEST professor I have ever had at SFU. Not only was he so considerate about a death in my family at the beginning of the semester, he remembered this till the end of the semester and offered to give me an extension when he noticed I missed the final submission! His lectures are also hilarious and turn the dryest topics fun.

Tim is so funny, and he's so smart that he cleverly builds jokes into something as boring as history of psych. The course itself is really dull but Tim brings it alive, his tests are also fair and he removes questions everyone did bad on. Would love to take this prof for a different subject.

Awesome and reasonable prof!! Readings and assignments might be hard to understand but the exams are easier than expected! He would take responsibility for the questions in the exam. Also love how he added a lot humours into the exam questions :D
Awesome prof!!!

Awesome dude, my only criticism is to make key points more clear. I think it would be really helpful if he released a study guide close to exams that gave a general idea of what we need to know. I wasted a lot of time on things that were not tested because what was in the "key concepts" section could be easily misinterpreted on what to get from it

very funny, very smart (too smart) can talk about the topic for 3hrs but if you're not good at in-class note taking, I'd give this a miss. No offence to him, he's really nice but it's extremely difficult to study for exams with no textbook, and only vague lecture notes to go on. the two papers, I found personally difficult, but that's just me.

Timothy is respected and hilarious at the same time. He is completely fair and attentive to his students. His exams aren't hard too if you study the lecture notes well. Please take this class with him!

So glad I took 308 with Tim. Instead of presenting a historical timeline, he expects you to think critically about WHY history is presented the way it is. The last 20 mins of class is solely for Q&A! Don't listen to to the person below me, you WILL need the textbook for readings and to flesh out the lecture notes. Study hard, the tests aren't easy!

For his first time teaching the course, he wasn't so bad. There is a lot of history in this course obviously most of the material in lectures is testable. Better to go than skip! Scaled midterm makes cause average was low and consequently made the final all based on lecture instead of textbook+lecture, which helped tons! Pretty funny dude too!

Most of the course is based on lectures so go! He's actually a decent lecturer, but it's history so a bit boring. Assignments weren't too hard. This was his first time teaching the course so it was a bit bumpy. He scaled the exams which was nice. We didn't end up using the textbook for the 2nd half of the course which made me mad  cause it was $$$$

He's funny, but his domain of teaching is evolutionary psychology. Lectures were brutal to sit through, but mandatory if you want a good grade. Exams require more than memorization, you need to know epistemologies and compare between different historiographies and perspectives. He scaled marks up since the class average was low.

Based on Fall 2019 semester: Exceptional prof, have taken other classes with him, passionate. His lectures are discussion based but he gives the option to respond on an online poll. Five critical papers to write based on readings (450 words). Clear grading criteria. TA gave good marks and every paper deadline was extended.

There is a small quiz or an assignment due each class so you can't skip, but if you pay attention and follow instructions you'll be fine. Enjoyable course, Joe is super nice and attentive, acts like he wants to be there which makes a difference.
Good prof. Learned a lot in his class. If you go to class you'll do fine. Would recommend.
Easy marker. GPA booster. Constantly scaling quizes and assignments so grades go way up. Marks papers very quickly and gives good marks.

I don't think i learned a single thing from this class. I don't get what Joe was trying to teach us every week for 3 hours but it was clearly not a history class like i thought. He lectured about absolutely nothing, must just like the sound of his voice. He also moves deadlines around without any notice and adds quizzes to the syllabus throughout.

Not the best prof ever. I have just had him for this course, but I wasn't impressed. It's so confusing and unclear to take his class. I feel that if you like an organized and focused course, this won't work for you. The class is all over the place, and he isn't very clear as to what he wants. Oh, also a very tough grader.

Joe seems like a nice professor, but don't let that fool you. When it comes to marking assignments, he is very unfair. Although the class is supposed to be about critical thinking, it is not. The way it is goes like this: either you agree with his or the TA's point of view, or you get a lower grade. Not fair regarding grading "though course."
This class ended up being quite beneficial for me in terms of writing papers. Could use a textbook but other than that, I found it challenging and Joe provided great feedback.

Joe is a very inexperienced professor. When it comes to history class, he tends to give extremely difficult to read articles and is extremely hard in marking. Also, he is very unclear as to what he wants. This course is only about critical thinking and knowing about history doesn't matter. I would not recommend. Stay away from him! You'll thank me!

This was not a too difficult course as Dr. Martin gave you the topics for the inclass writing assignments (ICW). Attending lectures is good as he explains thoroughly what you are expected to write for the assignments. However, lectures were pretty dry and not very engaging. He sometimes just read off his text so this added more boredom to the class

Not sure what people are talking about when they recommend this prof. Whole course grade based on 3 writing assignments. Even though I went to every class, took notes, did readings and prepared extensively for in class writing assignments, I still got an average grade. Exam questions were not straightforward and marking was extremely unreasonable

Dr. Martin tells history by using 'stories' and he does it well although the lectures can get a bit long and boring. It's important to come because there are little details you should remember for the the assignments. The assignments are fair but I suggest asking the TA's a bunch of questions beforehand because they are the ones who mark it.
Work load are all in class writing and will be given topics to prepare first. Although there are lots of things you need to study, you will do well if you prepare ready.

Loved him! He was rly helpful and kind. u dont need to come to every class, since slides cover everything. TAKE ADVANTAGE of office hrs and  be friends with ur TA - they mark ur papers; so talk to them and get help when needed.  Got A- becuz i asked TA for clarification each time (evn tho I skipped often lol oop)

I took this course with another prof but i dropped it before the first midterm -- that's how much i hated history. but with Dr. Martin it's a different story. he and his TA are just so awesome! no textbooks, marks are based on three in-class writings. he gave two possible topics two weeks ahead so you get more than enough time to prepare. TAKE IT!!

Jack is a brilliant man - and not in a pompous way! You will respect him and his intelligence immensely by taking 308 with him. I personally hate history but he made it bearable. He really wants us to succeed and gives us many opportunities to prepare for the in class writing assignments. no textbook, no exams but you must attend lecture to do well

If you're into history, you will enjoy this class. Lectures are NOT recorded and discussions follow each lecture. Easy to pass if you read the articles, lecture notes, and write papers in advance. There will be three in-class essay assignments - one of two essay questions will be asked. You will have two weeks to prepare for each assignment.

There is no required text but that being said, read the provided articles! He's a great speaker, his lectures are organized as stories which have proven to be fairly interesting even though I've always associated "history" with boredom. He's even got a handwritten letter from BF Skinner! Awesome prof, all around.

An excellent prof with superb teaching skills. I truly enjoyed all the lectures and found all the articles he'd selected for reading very useful. The three in-class written assignments weren't extremely hard IF you'd studied. Great structure - great course. I wish all the profs at SFU were this knowledgeable and articulate.

This course was way easier than I thought. Had 3 in-class writing assignments that consisted of 3 questions. We were given 2 possible questions 2 weeks in advance and were asked to answer 1 of them on the day. I definitely recommend going to see the TA before preparing your paper. They're the ones that are going to mark it.

Awesome prof! I was dreading the class prior to semester but it ended up being my favourite class. He teaches history like a story, cracks jokes and makes class engaging. In class writing assignments are straight forward; participate in discussion, talk to the TA bc she marks them, and prep a couple of days in advance.

Great prof! No assignments or exams- only 3 in class essays (pick 1 out of 2 questions) AND he gives them to you 2 weeks ahead! Lots of time to prepare using articles & in class discussion. Attendance is mandatory because you discuss the essay questions as a group
No textbook required
